General, simple and property tables

General <table>

Most tables are common tables, wrapped in a <table> element. You can also add a title to common tables, by inserting a <title> element into the <table> element. If you add a title to your table, avoid using generic titles like "Table 1". Always specify which information the users can find in the table. The next figure shows an example of a table in DITA.

<simpletable>

If you do not need a title for your table, you can also use a simple table. For example, a title can be unnecessary when the topic title already accurately describes the content of the table. By not including a title, you avoid repeating the topic title in the table title.

Tip: Instead of using a simple table, you can also use a common table and omit the <title> element.
For example, in this case, it is not necessary to add a title to the table. The content of the table is already clear from the topic title and the introductory text:

<properties>

Unlike common tables and simple tables, properties tables are only valid in reference topics. You can use the <properties> element to create a table that lists types, values and descriptions of properties. See Properties table.
